After the Indians have pounded the root, the hold it in a sieve under a running stream, which separates the finer portions with a little fiber (Starchy matter!) the greater part of the fibrous part remaining in the Seine.  It is from this finer part, that the bread is made, & when prepared has a light reddish colour, [crossed out: and has [?] somewhat around the taste of wheat bread it is said]  The Coshatta indians who reside below this prepare a bread from this plant in a superior manner [superscript  x]  (They [?] as grow [crossed out: corn] maze, and for their "particular white friends" will pick cotton. Slavery & other obs upon Mexico in 1843 [superscript X]
When Mexico seperated herself from old Spain, her new rulers, [crossed out: independently of [?] this ]?]]  declared the Negros free, this did not fall upon the revolutionry leaders, but [crossed out: principally] upon the Old Spaniards declaring the Negro free gave in the eyes of the U.S. & England & company a humane character - here was the tab thrown to whole, & contributed to the recognition of 6 anti-Slavery govts thus some Negros were dragged in chains to the Army, whilst others now being fee - the majority left their Masters & homes, wandered about, until starvation forced them to apply for work so as to obtain food & they now became hired Servants.  Their Masters soon got them into debt, & now they were really slaves again.   If they wanted to change Masters, which was not easily done, the new Master had to pay the debt which was run up against him - such as all the crockery he had broken or any thing else - If he lost or broke a hoe

Slavery - I am informed that the number of Whity Brown Slaves in Mexico is abut 2 to 2 ½ Millions! [superscript +x] and at Exeter Hall the long eared gentry aided by O'Connell Know not how to villify enough Texas when a few planters & farmers, who would not suffer a Military ?dispol? inflicted on them by Mexicanos laborers settled the Wilderness, & brought in about some 12 to 15,000 Negros who are much better off than the Mexican Peons - he is well clad, well fed & tho' he bears the name of Slave, if he be not a "bad Nigger" he will pass his life easily [crossed out: & happily]   Many Negros have left their Masters & gone to Mexico, but some I have seen who in a few Months have been tired of Mexican freedom [pencilled insert:  Mr Neil on his way to Perota says he met many runaway Negros in Mexico, who prayed to get back to Texas
[Note +X]  It is asserted that nine-tenths of the population of Mexico, are Enemies to Santana & kept down by the force of the bayonet.

clothing was supplied at prices the most exhorbitant & often the true Negro found himself in debt from 3 to 500$.  If he had the temerity to discuss the point, the "prison for debt" stared him in the face, & he was forced to go into Slavery again to a new Master -  Now comes another species of Slavery, & shows the heartless humbug of declaring "todo Mejicano libre".
Reverting to the "times of the Old Spaniards & bringing it up to the Republica period & I learn that the majority of "Mexicanos libres" are really as much slaves as the Negros in the W. Indies ere Britain gave 20 Millions to free them -  The Conqueros of Mexico had large tracts of land alloted to them, as they took any quantity they required calling it an "Encomenda" & all the Indians upon it they was called a "Repartimento - hard work particularly that of Mining reduced by premature death the

After a time a new law spring up by the Mexican being a mixture of Spaniard, Indian & Negro - forming a most motley community - & this debated have Succeeded in driving from the country aided by treachery of royalist troops nearly all the old^Spanish Grachupin blood.  Now then the tribes? Mexicans!  having become Masters & the property of the old Spaniards. became also masters of the Peon & thus families viz the lower orders or laborer's in a county who wish just in the same state as the free Negro already described - The Sanchez estates have upon them 10,000 Peons (slaves) & I should like to know how many White-Brown Slaves Santana President of Mexico is Master of.  In a Word the Peon is a Slave - & Peonage*

Santana
I am informed that Santana is a most parsimonious and miserly, amassing money & lands at a most extraordinary rate, he is not a young man - his riches may [?] in sustaining him in tottering power - His Wife is described as a most slatternly woman, & generally found  'in Mexican deshabille' - A pretty pair!  On one occasion he invited some fellows to dine with him, but requested them to bring their own wine! for he thought strong liquors very bad - What a catch for Father Matthew & his followers.  The blood-thirsty, treaty-breaking, ungrately? Santana!

  His enemies are many, but some how or other he keeps them quiet, but armed forces who obey him, creatures who can only rise and keep commands, by acceedy to his measures - On the occasion, he sent for Arista who was in command of the Texan frontier watching until a friendly eye the movements of the Traitor Genl

Canales to the Texans (he lured many Teams into Mexico to fight for the Federal constitution of 1824, & having practically gained his point,  turned round & masacerred his Texan adherents - this act wont tell well in his favor with Santana)  Arista suspected that a prison awaited him for he only took an escort, & to go with his division would be a declaration of War against the President - Arista sent a message that he was very sick.  Santana waited some time & sent again - he was a little better, but his sate of convalescence prevents just then waiting upon the President.  A few weeks passed.  When Santana sent to say that he would send a military force to bring him into presence.  Arista's reply was that, he was well enough now to resist any troops that might be sent against him.  He heard no more some time from Santana, when a very polite dispatch arrived from Mexico - Commending his services & patriotism

S.   Santana's life has been often attempted, and many ingenious plans have been resorted to.  Once a rich Musical gold snuff-box with precious stones, in which was secreted a small pistol & so arranged that in winding it up to a certain pitch, the pistol would off.  Santana suspecting that all was right, turned it about, the result being that the conspirator got himself shot dead - With regard to the ignorance even of Mexican Generals - Mr D? when prisoner ^1842 at Monterey, was treated kindly by Gl Reyes, & who questioned him about the Texan Army &c -
How many troops can you call into the field in a month?  20,000.  How do you make that out?  I calculate it from the number of Votes polled, & a number of boys who can handle the Rifle well - Where are your troops stationed?  In their own Lands on their own plantations.  How are they to be armed & clothed & provisioned?  Each Citizen soldier, funds himself & each has a good horse, & a good horn of powder & 50 bullets

Texas a young & gallant republic.  A few years since, but an obscure territory of Mexico - a Wilderness.

   The course of Texas is a romance in history - a strange problem in political philosophy - an act in the great drama of demography
   Her population are adventurous Emigrants from the United States & Europe, who went there, conquered a great extent of country, organized themselves in a republic, & have maintained themselves by their valor industry & wisdom.
  This had been recognized by the U. States, England, France, Belgium & the Hanseatic States [?] have treaties with her.
  In a few years Texas will have a great influence on Mexico {?] & may absorb many of her poor [?]
  Let old Europe look & wonder at the progress of self-government & civilization in the New World.

Expedition in Steamer Lafitte  Original notes
Journied on P. steamer Lafitte John Wade Commander - March 14, 1842. Monday.  After a few days - the Inhabitnats have promised a ?tt..ent?] for [?] here - [?] have took of Gentlemen Volunteers they are - In the afternoon left Galveston - Mr Santa Ana & Wastinton? Wilkinson.
March 15 Tuesday - During the night W.N. & Keeping about 6 sailors  from shore - got down [?] and made at [?Cabatto?] - the Bar pretty fair No one should come without pilot -
Wednesday 16th  Failure? on those exercising - vague rumors only & the Mexicans [?Exoring?]] at Ecidgunas? - Pipe? & infantry invade - appoint Sargeant of [?] division - Went on then to café with Baron Thilebocanst? & lady - they know not what to do - & they will not be able to do much apparently
Thursday 17  At daylight got under weigh & a few miles it of Esperita Santa Inlet - beat to quarter for a sail to Leeward - boarded her - a try only from Mobile with ?..nder  When off E.L. lnlet saw a Sloop ashore under suspicious circumstances - [?] down to her manned rig? & away they went - they got into the breakers - 2 apart - for some moments we thought we had lost some of our help - but they soon got a ashore - The Washington came up with us - we then them dry cloths for the rigs & we then bore off for San [Gigs?]] crew to sail in tomorrow in Aransas Bay - Got over Aransas bar very well - & came to anchor for the night
Friday 18th Daylight got under weigh - fell in with the Santana and our Gig - 10 am came to anchor Live Oak pc this is a pretty country - & in the vicinity are some fine Indians (Corrujuas San Kansas) they are friendly were driven out of the State X had the reputation of being Canibals
faint unclear writing
at bottom of page
All those [?] have plenty fine fish

type_os: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01, resolution (DPI), density 300x300, segment length 16, Exif Standard: [TIFF image data, little-endian, direntries=6, manufacturer=Canon, model=Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III, software=Adobe Photoshop Camera Raw 6.6 (Macintosh),

element_texts.text: Completed

Saturday 19th  Cloudy weather all gone - fine & clear with beautiful breezes - What would the Cockneys give for such a climate - 2 PM Came too off Copano.  Capt Wade went ashore - all the men gone only a few ladies left - they inform us that it was reported that 300 of our men had gone thro' the Mission (Refuges) a few days since on their way South - 5 PM Made for Black Pt. the S.E. part of Copano Bay to take on wood - Shoals & sand Banks - but with care there is no danger - keep this land on port going - we draw 5 fts and get along famously - Tide appears to run strong - bark comes to anchor after piloting for a passage in Copano Bay 6 fts.
Sunday 20 - No 1 got under enough - & made Black Pt. in an hour - abrufts? leaving coast - only one family came Mr. Armstrong Sent an Express off to Inform (Refuges) about 15 miles -  from this place we expect to have news pacbontarly? of our own party - Left too Wooding - [?] went at it - he loaded & all day - Wood.  The Musquite rather sweet   Lots from strong firewood - The Musquite is of the Acacian species  -Emand? gallon flower. & Musquite grass fine for catch-  The Breeze seaspray now the [?] was laden with the sweet smelling perfumes of its flowers - Had a shoot in the afternoon - Saw plenty rabbits - Deer abounding themselves - The sound of the saw our cording party has scared them - This must be a fine country for game & fish.  The Shores of this Bay must be crowded with habitantus - [?] cities to conduct the Corssaal? Islands with the intention & with exporting of its produce.  The Poultry on Shore are large - Mr. Branstroy complains of a partial drought for the last 11 months - Saw some of the [?] (ivopal)
Monday 21st   Wooding working? all day - Express returned - brought us no more news than we had before - On the 7th a party of Mexicans came on at Sn Patrius & killed Messrs Carnes, Snodgrass Wells & Willis & some 4 Lipan Indians - the following day they came down - some 40 of them to Corpus Christi distributed Aristas? proclamation & started off towards the Rio Grand - Why was not something done at Corpus Christi to revenge the deaths of Carnes & his friends?!
Tuesday 22nd  8 am got under weigh for Live Oak Pt around noon - got some water - we got the wells dry - 
Miss No #? Champagned Miss No I - passed Ibant? every or enemy?

It would appear that the powerful force of the Mexican marching army is at Montery about 10 000 strong - Al Moncton says [?] 3000 - From these places Arista sent his proclamation into (Texas of which no one will believe a word) with some 6 to 700 men and those disarmed - to Spy into our readiness for War - According to their reports & our belligerent Manifestations Arista will not - He may invade with his whole force - & if he does those that we have already in the field will thrash him - We may lose some few but the Victory will be ours [?] up & doing - by land & sea & all that can result in my poor opinion is to keep us a hot water & their finest the getting in at the [?] - some of them we have already - Our fleet under Commodore [?] is to the South - We are watching the coast with our Small but very efective [sic] squadrons.  Our land forces & volunteers muster pretty strong along the San Antonio & [?] of that [?] - and doubtless our friends on the Mississippi are forming in to operations - and it [?] not be a matter of astonishment if one fine morning the Texas Flag [?shows up here?] floating over Monterey - & what may follow if a muster strong enough may surprise the west [?] of Santana himself
Wednesday 23rd  Accompd Capt Wade & others in 'Washington' to Corpus Christi - had to beat down - [?] land for S.E. arrived at 3.30 PM - High bluff land - Saw [?] Kenney & Aubrey - & the rest of the inhabitants - (? Holmes & Hopkins?) Carver & his party, had been for some time acting as a Guard to this place - they had gone out against the wish of the people here - & were found by a party of Mexicans under [?] asleep in the Middle of the day & Killed them - Cameron only escaping - [?] having an old spite against [?] [?] has gone off to the Army & will make his report - [?] effects abou 18 inches C. Cristi 2 papers the N the one short & narrow 4 ½ to 5 ft there is no water in it.  Aransas 8 to 10 ft - Anibaje at [?] full We made that out to chance away & then C. Christi to Bay could be rendered navigable

for the Eastern Counties it is asserted that there will soon be a place in the middle country the hope only but the Colorado^ & Western people have no faith in so desirable a consumation.  Some TonKanways bring intelligence that even upon the ?inces there is a Mexican Military force, and that they have heard their Bugles and Bands play.   in other ? the TonKanways killed  some of their Scouts & ?  From the Mexican Traders we hear that Military preparations are going on on the Rio Grande.   The Commissioners may meet & the Knowing ones here say there will be stormy discussion & nothing done.   The T.C. will return home and then we may expect another military promenade say of some 5000 Men.   Then as the U.S. E & F. have a finger in the fire, the crust may be broken irregularly & the contents of the dish distributed quien sabe.   This will interfere with Colonization of the West -
